Fun Fact: The a lot of those impurities in the glycerol are called phytosterols, which are closely related to cholesterol. Phytosterols are estrogenic in nature and can effect testosterone levels in men. Which isn't surprising because sterols sound a lot like steroids, and are the feedstock for synthetic Testosterone, Cortisone, and a whole bunch of other hormones.

I hope you use this comment as constructive criticism, When i type in how to make something such as glycerol or ethanol I expect a step by step instruction on how to do it. Your videos are experiments and basically a Vlog of what transpired and allot of times you even mention your not particularly sure what certain things are in your beakers and you assume there certain things. Its also evident that this is the first time you made Glycerin. That is not an instructional video and surely a title like "How to make Vegetable Glyecerin" is misleading as I watch 8 minutes of a Vlog instead of a step by step instructional video by someone who has done this before and knows what there doing. one of the problems with such a video is allot of times this is not the best way or most effective way of producing whatever you are filming. Perhaps recording an instructional video after youve done it 2 or 3 times would make the video more useful. Your video titles should be more like "Trying to make Glycerin" or "Attempting to make ethanol heres what happened". I watched afew of your videos and have basically the same comment on most of them. Hope this helps

@Nile Red: A quick remark I learned in my first chemistry lab back in UG - don't ever throw a magnetic bar into a flask (as in 1:50). It has the potential to break the glass (especially when the flask is staying on a magnetic stirrer) and/or spill chemicals. Always insert it slowly and carefully while maintaining the flask in an angle.

Keep up the good work!
